facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 34 of 1953 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 34 of 1953.

facts.text: Appeal from Judgment and Order dated 5th January 1953 of High Court of Judicature at Allahabad Lucknow Bench.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and Order dated the 5th January, 1953, of the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad  Lucknow Bench , Lucknow  Kidwai and Bhargava JJ.

facts.text: High Court case: Criminal Appeal Register No. 24 of 1952 and Capital Sentence Register No. 4 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: in Criminal Appeal Register No. 24 of 1952 and Capital Sentence Register No. 4 of 1952 arising out of the Judgment and Order dated the 19th January 1952,

facts.text: Arising from Sessions Case No. 97 of 1951, Judgment dated 19th January 1952 of Sessions Judge Sitapur.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the Judgment and Order dated the 19th January 1952, of the Court of the Sessions Judge, Sitapur, in Sessions Case No. 97 of 1951.

facts.text: Three appellants prosecuted for murder of Babu Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by BOSE J.We have three appellants before us. All were prosecuted for the murder of one Babu Singh.

facts.text: Surendra Singh convicted of murder and sentenced to death.

anchor.surface_text: Of these, Surendra Singh alone was companyvicted of the murder and was sentenced to death.

facts.text: Other two appellants convicted under section 225 Indian Penal Code, sentenced to three years rigorous imprisonment and fine of Rs. 200.

anchor.surface_text: The other two were companyvicted under section 225, Indian Penal Code. Each was sentenced to three years rigorous imprisonment and to a fine of Rs. 200.

facts.text: All three appealed to High Court at Allahabad Lucknow Bench.

anchor.surface_text: All three appealed to the High Court at Allahabad  Lucknow Bench  and the appeal was heard on Filth December, 1952,

facts.text: High Court appeal heard on 5th December 1952 by Kidwai and Bhargava JJ.

anchor.surface_text: and the appeal was heard on Filth December, 1952, by Kidwai and Bhargava JJ.  Judgment was reserved.

facts.text: Bhargava J. transferred to Allahabad before judgment delivered.

anchor.surface_text: Before it companyld be delivered Bhargava J. was transferred to Allahabad.

facts.text: Bhargava J. dictated judgment purporting to be joint judgment using 'we', signed every page but did not date it.

anchor.surface_text: While there he dictated a, judgment purporting to do so on behalf of himself and his brother Judge, that is to say it purported to be a joint judgment he used the pronoun we and number I. He signed every page of the judgment as well as at the end but did number date it.

facts.text: Bhargava J. sent the judgment to Kidwai J. at Lucknow.

anchor.surface_text: He then sent this to Kidwai J. at Lucknow.

facts.text: Bhargava J. died on 24th December 1962.

anchor.surface_text: He died on 24th December, 1962, before the judgment was delivered.

facts.text: On 5th January 1953, Kidwai J. purported to deliver the judgment of the court, signed and dated it 5th January 1953.

anchor.surface_text: After his death, on 5th January, 1953, his brother Judge Kidwai J. purported to deliver the judgment of the companyrt. He signed it and dated it. The date he placed on it was 5th January, 1953,

facts.text: Bhargava J.'s signature was on the judgment delivered by Kidwai J.

anchor.surface_text: Bhargava J.s signature was still there and anyone reading the judgment and number knowing the facts would companyclude that Bhargava J. was a party to the delivery on 5th January, 1953.

facts.text: High Court dismissed the appeal and confirmed the death sentence.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal was dismissed and the sentence of death was companyfirmed.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court Rules framed in 1952, came into force 15th September 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The Allahabad High Court framed its present set of Rules in 1952. They came into force on the 15th of September in that year.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on 1953 November 16 by BOSE J.

anchor.surface_text: 1953. November 16. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by BOSE J.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds High Court judgment invalid due to death of Bhargava J. before delivery.

anchor.surface_text: Our companyclusion is that the judgment which Kidwa,i J. purported to deliver on 5th January, 1953, was number a valid judgment because the other member of the Bench died before it companyld be delivered.

facts.text: Supreme Court allows appeal, sets aside High Court order, remands for rehearing.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is allowed and the order of the High Court which purports to be its judgment is set aside. As it is numberlonger possible for the Bench which heard the appeal and the companyfirmation proceedings to deliver a valid judgment we send the case back to the High Court for re-hearing and delivery of a proper judgment.

facts.text: Order for stay dated 25th May 1953 has no more effect, dated 1953 November 23.

anchor.surface_text: 1953. November 23. BOSE J.The order for stay dated the 25th May, 1953, has number expended itself.

facts.text: High Court judgment heard by Kidwai and Bhargava JJ.

anchor.surface_text: Chapter VII dealing with the judgment and decree, namely rules 1.4. These rules provide for four different situations  1  for judgments which are pronounced at once as soon as the case has been heard  2  for those which are pronounced on some future date,  3  for judgments which are oral, and  4  for those which are written.

issues.text: whether this judgment could be validly delivered after the death of one of the two Judges who heard the appeal

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether this judgment could be validly delivered after the death of one of the two Judges who heard the appeal. The arguments covered a wide range but we intend to confine ourselves to the facts of this case and only deal

court_response_anchor.surface_text: as- sumes more importance than ever in a criminal case because of section 369 of the Criminal Procedure Code which provides

arguments.court_reasoning: We do not intend to construe these rules too technically because they are designed, as indeed are all rules, to further the ends of justice and must not be viewed too narrowly

arguments.claim: Irregularities in judgment procedure like failure to sign due to death or leave are curable by inherent jurisdiction and sections 99 and 108 CPC

anchor.surface_text: As this decision of the Judicial Committee was relied on in the arguments we will quote the passage which is relevant here. It is at page 295 of Firm Gokal Chand v. Firm Nand Ram. The facts are not the same as here because the judgment was actually delivered in open court and both the judges who constituted the Bench were present and concurred in it. But before it could be signed, one Judge went on leave. A.I.R. 1938 P.C. 292. The rules required the judgment to be signed and dated at the time that it was pronounced. Their Lordships said- The rule does not say that if its requirements are not complied with the judgment shall be a nullity. So startling a result would need clear and precise words. Indeed the rule does not even state any definite time in which it is to be fulfilled. The time is left to be defined by what is reasonable. The rule from its very nature is not intended to affect the rights of parties to a judgment. It is intended to secure certainty in the ascertainment of what the judgment was. It is a rule which Judges are required to comply with for that object. No doubt in practice Judges do so comply, as it is their duty to do. But accidents may happen. A Judge may die after giving judgment but before he has had a reasonable opportunity to sign it. The court must have inherent jurisdiction to supply such a defect. The case of a Judge who has gone on leave before signing the judgment may call for more comment, but even so the convenience of the court and the interest of litigants must prevail. The defect is merely an irregularity. But in truth the difficulty is disposed of by sections 99 and 108, Civil Procedure Code.

arguments.court_reasoning: That was a civil case. This is a criminal one. But section 537 of the Criminal Procedure Code does much the same thing on the criminal side as sections 99 and 108 do on the civil. The principle underlying them is the same. But even after every allowance is made... the question still remains what is a judgment

arguments.claim: Section 537 CrPC cures irregularities in criminal proceedings similar to sections 99 and 108 CPC in civil

anchor.surface_text: section 537 of the Criminal Procedure Code does much the same thing on the criminal side as sections 99 and 108 do on the civil. The principle underlying them is the same.

arguments.claim: A judgment is the final decision of the court intimated to the parties and to the world at large by formal pronouncement or delivery in open court

anchor.surface_text: a judgment within the meaning of these sections is the final decision of the court intimated to the parties and to the world at large by formal pronouncement or delivery in open court. It is a judicial act which must be performed in a judicial way.

arguments.claim: No court shall alter or review judgment after signing except to correct clerical error per section 369 CrPC

anchor.surface_text: section 369 of the Criminal Procedure Code which provides that Save as otherwise provided by this Code or by any other law for the time being in force or, in the case of a High Court, by the Letters Patent or other instrument constituting such High Court, no court, when it has signed its judgment, shall alter or review the same except to correct a clerical error.

arguments.claim: Judges have locus poenitentiae and right to change mind until formal delivery of judgment

anchor.surface_text: Now up to the moment the judgment is delivered Judges have the right to change their mind. There is a sort of locus poenitentiae, and indeed last minute alterations sometimes do occur. Therefore, however much a draft judgment may have been signed beforehand, it is nothing but a draft till formally delivered as the judgment of the court.

arguments.claim: The judge who delivers or causes delivery must be alive at the moment of delivery to allow possible change of mind

anchor.surface_text: It follows that the Judge who delivers the judgment, or causes it to be delivered by a brother Judge, must be in existence as a member of the court at the moment of delivery so that he can, if necessary, stop delivery and say that he has changed his mind.

arguments.claim: Against public policy to investigate whether a signed draft was final opinion or tentative

anchor.surface_text: We feel it would be against public policy to leave the door open for an investigation whether a draft sent by a Judge was intended to embody his final and unalterable opinion or was only intended to be a tentative draft sent with an unwritten understanding that he is free to change his mind

arguments.claim: Drafts or signed opinions handed in before delivery are not formal judgments; must be pronounced in open court

anchor.surface_text: Views similar to this were expressed by a Full Bench of the Calcutta High Court consisting of nine Judges in the year 1867 in Mahomed Akil v. Asadunnissa Bibee. In that case, three of the seven Judges who constituted the Bench handed in signed judgments to the Registrar of the court. Before the judgment could be delivered, two of them retired and one died. ... Jackson J. expressed the law aright in these words- I have however always understood that it was necessary in strict practice that judgments should be delivered and pronounced in open court.

arguments.claim: Judgment purportedly delivered by Kidwai J. on 5th January 1953 was not valid because Bhargava J. died before delivery

anchor.surface_text: Our conclusion is that the judgment which Kidwai J. purported to deliver on 5th January, 1953, was not a valid judgment because the other member of the Bench died before it could be delivered.

holdings.text: The judgment which Kidwai J. purported to deliver on 5th January, 1953, was not a valid judgment because the other member of the Bench died before it could be delivered.

anchor.surface_text: Our conclusion is that the judgment which Kidwai J. purported to deliver on 5th January, 1953, was not a valid judgment because the other member of the Bench died before it could be delivered.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Formal delivery in open court required for judgment to be final; death of judge ends locus poenitentiae; public policy bars inquiry into draft intent; precedents confirm delivery essential.

holdings.text: A judgment within the meaning of these sections is the final decision of the court intimated to the parties and to the world at large by formal pronouncement or delivery in open court. It is a judicial act which must be performed in a judicial way.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, a judgment within the meaning of these sections is the final decision of the court intimated to the parties and to the world at large by formal pronouncement or delivery in open court. It is a judicial act which must be performed

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rules ensure certainty in judgment; s369 emphasizes finality post-signing and delivery; core substance is formal intimation, not mere draft.

holdings.text: The rules are not to be construed too technically as they are designed to further the ends of justice and must not be viewed too narrowly.

anchor.surface_text: We do not intend to construe these rules too technically because they are designed, as indeed are all rules, to further the ends of justice and must not be viewed too narrowly nor do we desire to curtail the jurisdiction

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects strict distinction between 'pronounced' and 'delivered'; substance over form for Allahabad HC Rules Ch VII.

holdings.text: Up to the moment the judgment is delivered Judges have the right to change their mind. There is a sort of locus poenitentiae.

anchor.surface_text: Now up to the moment the judgment is delivered Judges have the right to change their mind. There is a sort of locus poenitentiae, and indeed last minute alterations sometimes do occur.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pre-delivery acts are tentative; formal delivery crystallizes judgment; allows last-minute changes.

holdings.text: The Judge who delivers the judgment, or causes it to be delivered by a brother Judge, must be in existence as a member of the court at the moment of delivery so that he can, if necessary, stop delivery and say that he has changed his mind.

anchor.surface_text: It follows that the Judge who delivers the judgment, or causes it to be delivered by a brother Judge, must be in existence as a member of the court at the moment of delivery so that he can, if necessary, stop delivery and say that he has

holdings.reasoning_summary: Derives from locus poenitentiae; judge must be alive to exercise right to alter; physical presence not required but existence as court member is.

holdings.text: It would be against public policy to leave the door open for an investigation whether a draft sent by a Judge was intended to embody his final and unalterable opinion or was only intended to be a tentative draft.

anchor.surface_text: We feel it would be against public policy to leave the door open for an investigation whether a draft sent by a Judge was intended to embody his final and unalterable opinion or was only intended to be a tentative draft sent with an unwritten

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prevents uncertainty and speculation on judge's final intent; drafts remain tentative until delivery; supported by Calcutta Full Bench precedent.

holdings.text: Small irregularities in the manner of pronouncement or the mode of delivery do not matter but the substance of the thing must be there... All the rest the manner in which it is to be recorded, the way in which it is to be authenticated the signing and the sealing... can be cured but not the hard core, namely the formal intimation of the decision.

anchor.surface_text: Small irregularities in the manner of pronouncement or the mode of delivery do not matter but the substance of the thing must be there that can neither be bluffed nor left to inference and conjecture nor can it be vague. All the rest the manner

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes curable authentication defects (s537 CrPC, inherent jurisdiction) from incurable absence of formal delivery; applies s99/108 CPC analogy limitedly.

holdings.text: Section 537 of the Criminal Procedure Code does much the same thing on the criminal side as sections 99 and 108 do on the civil. The principle underlying them is the same.

anchor.surface_text: That was a civil case. This is a criminal one. But section 537 of the Criminal Procedure Code does much the same thing on the criminal side as sections 99 and 108 do on the civil. The principle underlying them is the same.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonizes civil and criminal curing provisions but does not extend to core judgment delivery defect.

precedents.case_name: Firm Gokal Chand v. Firm Nand Ram
precedents.cited_proposition: Courts have inherent jurisdiction to cure irregularities in the authentication of judgments such as failure to sign timely due to accidents like death or leave; such defects do not render the judgment a nullity but are curable under procedural provisions analogous to sections 99 and 108 CPC or section 537 CrPC.
precedents.cited_holding: The rule does number say that if its requirements are number companyplied with the judgment shall be a nullity. [...] The companyrt must have inherent jurisdiction to supply such a defect. The defect is merely an irregularity.

precedents.citation: Mahomed Akil v. Asadunnissa Bibee 1 9 W.R.I. F.B.

anchor.surface_text: Views similar to this were expressed by a Full Bench of the Calcutta High Court companysisting of nine Judges in the year 1867 in Mahomed Akil v. Asadunnissa Bibee 1 . In that case, three of the seven Judges who companystituted the Bench handed in signed judgments to the Registrar of the companyrt. Before the judgment companyld be delivered, two of them retired and one died. [...] 1 9 W.R.I. F.B.

precedents.cited_proposition: Signed draft judgments cannot be treated as formal judgments of the court unless delivered and pronounced in open court; judges who die or retire before delivery cannot participate in the judgment.
precedents.cited_holding: it was necessary in strict practice that judgments should be delivered and pronounced in open companyrt. [...] Judges who have died or have retired from the companyrt cannot join in the judgment which is to be delivered today [...] A judgment in the eye of the law is the final decision of the whole companyrt.
